Fig. 1 TEM images of fresh sulfided (a) 0.5 ML, (b) 1 ML, (c) 2 ML, and (d) 4 ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts (white arrows: CoMo-S species, white circles: CoMo-S layer, and black circles: stacked CoMo-S layers). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of ZrO2, 0.5 ML, 1 ML, 2 ML, and 4 ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images of fresh sulfided (a) Co/Mo = 0 (Mo-S), (b) Co/Mo = 0.1, (c) Co/Mo = 0.3, and (d) Co/Mo = 1.5 CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts (black arrows: Mo-S layers, black circles: dark spots (Mo-S species), white arrows: small spots (CoMo-S species), and white circles: CoMo-S layers). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 CO conversion during WGS reaction over n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts (Feed: 10 vol.% CO, 20 vol.% H2O, and 7000 ppm H2S in He at GHSV = 35,000 h−1). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Raman spectra of n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts collected at (a) 1.2 cm−1 and (b) 0.2 cm-1 step size. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 H2-TPR profiles of n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 CO conversion during WGS reaction over the Co/Mo = n and commercial CoMo catalysts (Feed: 10 vol.% CO, 20 vol.% H2O, and 7000 ppm H2S in He) at GHSV = 35,000 h−1 (Co/Mo = 0.1, 0.3, and 1.5) and 39,000 h-1 (Co/Mo = 0 and commercial CoMo catalyst). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Raman spectra of the Co/Mo = n catalysts collected at (a) 1.2 cm−1 and (b) 0.2 cm-1 step size. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 H2-TPR profiles of Co/Mo = n catalysts. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 XPS-spectra (a) Mo 3d region and (b) S 2p region of Co/Mo = n catalysts. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 CO conversion during WGS reaction over Co/Mo = n and commercial CoMo catalysts (Feed: 10 vol.% CO, 20 vol.% H2O, and 7000 ppm H2S in He at GHSV = 35,000 h−1 and 350 °C). Fig. 11 Fig. 12 CO conversion over (a) n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 and (b) Co/Mo = n catalysts during WGS reaction employing 7000 ppm H2S-containing and H2S-free feed (Feed: 10 vol.% CO, and 20 vol.% H2O in He) at 350 °C and GHSV = 35,000 h−1 (39,000 h-1 for Co/Mo = 0 and commercial CoMo catalyst). Hydrogen production over Co-promoted Mo-S water gas shift catalysts supported on ZrO2 SeongUk Yun Vadim Guliants * Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH, 45221-0012, United States Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering University of Cincinnati Cincinnati OH 45221-0012 United States Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221-0012 ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A series of CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by modifying Co and Mo content using incipient wetness impregnation method, investigated in the water gas shift (WGS) reaction in the presence of H2S and characterized by TEM, XRD, Raman, TPR, and XPS. The supported CoMo-S catalyst corresponding to the CoMo-O monolayer coverage displayed the presence of highly dispersed CoMo-S species that were characterized by the highest extent of sulfidation. The presence of cobalt facilitated the formation of active CoMo-S species that were more H2S-dependent as compared to Mo-S entities. The Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst at monolayer CoMo-O coverage was the most active and thermally stable, as well as the least H2S-dependent during 4 weeks of WGS reaction among all catalysts investigated. Keywords Water gas shift reaction CoMo sulfide Surface coverage ZrO2 H2S dependence 1 Introduction Hydrogen is an environmentally friendly and high energy density (120 MJ/kg) molecule that can be used as a fuel for stationary electric power plants and mobile fuel cells with zero CO2 emissions [1–4]. Most hydrogen (∼96%) is currently produced from fossil fuel feedstocks: 48% from high-temperature steam reforming of natural gas, 30% from partial oxidation of refinery oil, and 18% from coal gasification [5,6]. The major challenges of using fossil fuels for hydrogen production are high CO2 emissions, the uneven distribution, and shortage of fossil fuel reserves [7]. However, hydrogen production from biomass-derived syngas could overcome these challenges, since biomass is a carbon-neutral and abundant sustainable energy resource [7–9]. The water gas shift (WGS) reaction is a key operation in maximizing the production of hydrogen from biomass-derived syngas [7,8]. As the WGS reaction is reversible and mildly exothermic, the WGS activity depends on reaction temperature ( C O ( g ) + H 2 O ( g ) ↔ C O 2 ( g ) + H 2 ( g ) [ Δ H 0 = - 41.1 k J / m o l ] ) [10,11]. Typical WGS reactors consist of a high-temperature shift (HTS, 350∼450 °C) and a low-temperature shift (LTS, ∼250 °C) stages due to the thermodynamic limitations of this reaction [10–12]. However, it is quite challenging to apply typical WGS catalysts in hydrogen production using biomass-derived syngas, since biomass feedstocks contain a considerable amount of sulfur [13]. The main challenge of using current Fe2O3-Cr2O3 HTS catalysts is the easy deactivation of these catalysts when the H2S concentration in the syngas exceeds 500 ppm [14], while the commercially available Cu–ZnO–Al2O3 (LTS) catalysts deactivate completely in the presence of trace levels of H2S (∼10 ppm) [15]. On the other hand, the molybdenum-based catalysts have gained significant interest as a sulfur-tolerant WGS catalyst in recent years. However, Mo-based catalysts are sulfur-dependent, requiring at least 100 ppm of H2S to display WGS activity [16]. Currently, no catalyst can maintain WGS activity over the entire range of sulfur content encountered in biomass (0 ∼ 15,000 ppm on dry basis) [13]. Moreover, the WGS activity of Mo-based catalysts is relatively low as compared to conventional HTS and LTS WGS catalysts, Fe- and Cu-based [11,17] and needs to be further improved for this application. As compared to traditional supports, such as alumina, ZrO2 is a promising support for Mo-based WGS catalysts because it can improve their catalytic activity due to weak MoO3-support interactions. For example, alumina-supported Mo catalysts pre-activated above 500 °C interacted strongly with Al2O3 and displayed lower activity in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of thiophene than these catalysts pre-activated below 400 °C [18]. On the other hand, Shetty et al. reported that the ZrO2-supported Mo catalysts characterized by weak interactions between ZrO2 and Mo species showed high catalytic activity in the hydrodeoxygenation of m-cresol to toluene [19]. The Mo/ZrO2 catalysts showed the greatest extent of MoO3 reduction to MoO2 among the ZrO2-, TiO2-, Al2O3-, SiO2-, and MgO-supported Mo catalysts [20], suggesting that MoO3 interacted weakly with ZrO2 support. The high density of surface Mo-O sites is traditionally achieved by enhancing their dispersion as a function of MoO3 surface coverage on oxide supports. High hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of anisole activity was observed over the Mo-O/ZrO2 catalysts containing a monolayer MoO3 surface coverage due to the presence of highly dispersed Mo oxide species [21]. Al2O3-supported Mo-based catalysts at monolayer MoO3 surface coverage showed the highest WGS activity [22,23]. The modified dispersion of Mo-O species on ZrO2 at different MoO3 loadings has been reported by Chary et al. [24]. However, the effects of CoMo-O surface coverage on ZrO2 support have not been widely studied in the WGS reaction. Several additives were proposed to promote the WGS activity of Mo-based catalysts. Alkali metal promoters have been suggested to improve the WGS activity by enhancing reducibility and sulfidation of Mo [25], while the high mobility of alkali promoters at high reaction temperature had a negative impact on the stability of Mo-based catalysts [26]. Nickel (Ni)-promoted Mo-S catalysts have been reported to show enhanced WGS activity and bimetallic synergistic effect [27–30], whereas the methanation side-reaction and increased carbon deposition are typical disadvantages of Ni-Mo catalysts for hydrogen production. Cobalt was reported as the optimal additive to improve the WGS activity of Mo-based catalysts by increasing the density of active sites [31–35]. CoMo-S/TiO2-Al2O3 catalysts showed higher WGS activity than commercial sour shift catalysts (CoMo-MgO-Al2O3) at H2O/CO = 1 [36,37]. The WGS reaction pathways for the Al2O3-supported Mo-S and Co-promoted Mo-S species have been investigated by DFT calculations and in experimental studies [38,39]. The CoMo-S and Mo-S sites in the CoMo-S/Al2O3 catalysts were distinguished and quantified using CO adsorption followed by in-situ IR spectroscopy (IR/CO) at low temperature [38,40]. Chen et al. reported that the intrinsic activity of CoMo-S sites in the WGS reaction at low temperature (< 300 °C) was higher than that of unpromoted Mo-S sites [38]. Recent DFT calculations over CoMo-S WGS catalysts reported that the overall reaction barrier for the COOH-associated mechanism proposed for the WGS reaction on the S edge of Co-MoS2 was lower than that of the redox mechanism on the S edge of MoS2 [39]. The Co addition can reduce the height of the H2O dissociation energy (H2O → OH + H) on the sulfur edge sites of Co-MoS2 as compared to that of unpromoted Mo-S [39,41], which is one of the rate-determining steps in the WGS reaction. We investigated two series of ZrO2 supported CoMo-S catalysts. In the first series, we investigated the influence of CoMo-O surface coverage ranging from 0.5 to 4 layers on ZrO2 on the WGS activity. In the second series, the effect of Co/Mo ratios at monolayer surface coverage were investigated. The long-term stability and H2S-dependence of CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts as a function of CoMo-O surface coverage and Co/Mo atomic ratios were also investigated employing an H2S containing feed, while both series of CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts were characterized by TEM, XRD, Raman, TPR, and XPS. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Supported CoMo catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of the ZrO2 support with a solution of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (Fisher Scientific) and cobalt nitrate (Alfa Aesar). Crushed and sieved 100 ∼ 500 μm particles of ZrO2 were employed, which were supplied by Saint-Gobain. After incipient impregnation with aqueous solutions of the Co and Mo precursors, the supported catalysts were dried overnight at 80 °C. The dried catalysts were then calcined at 500 °C in air for 5 h. The catalysts thus prepared were denoted as CoMo-O/ZrO2 (CoMo oxide catalyst). All catalysts were pre-sulfided in flowing 1 mol.% H2S in H2 at 450 °C for 18 h before catalytic tests. The pre-sulfided catalysts were denoted as CoMo-S/ZrO2. The first series of catalysts were prepared at 1.25, 2.5, 5, and 10 wt.% Mo relative to the ZrO2 support, while the Co weight loading was same as Mo. The catalysts were denoted as n-ML catalysts, where n stands for the number of theoretical CoMo-O surface layers (0.5, 1, 2, and 4.0 layers, respectively). The CoMo-O surface coverage of the catalysts ranging from 0.5 to 4 layers was controlled by the Co and Mo weight loadings during the catalyst synthesis by incipient wetness impregnation. The second series of catalysts were prepared at 5, 4, 1.95, and 2.5 wt.% Mo relative to the ZrO2 support, while the amount of Co was 0, 0.3, 0.6, and 2.5 wt.% depending on the Co/Mo atomic ratio to yield a theoretical monolayer coverage in all cases. This series of catalysts was denoted as Co/Mo = n catalysts, where n stands for the Co/Mo atomic ratio. The commercially available sour gas shift catalyst (ShiftMax 820) was provided by Clariant. The commercial catalyst contained 10.0 wt.% MoO3, 4.0 wt.% CoO, 18.0 wt.% MgO, and 68.0 wt.% Al2O3. The pelletized commercial catalyst was crushed and sieved to select 100 ∼ 500 μm sized particles. 2.2 WGS activity The catalytic activity of these WGS catalysts was determined by employing a fixed-bed tubular stainless reactor (0.65 cm ID) operated at atmospheric pressure. The feed gas mixture contained 10 vol.% CO, 20 vol.% H2O, and 0 ∼ 0.7 vol.% H2S in He. The total feed flow rate was 50 mL/min. Water was injected into a flowing feed gas mixture by a syringe pump and vaporized in a heated gas feed line before entering the reactor. A condenser filled with ice was installed at the reactor exit to collect water. The product gas mixture was analyzed by an HP-5890 II gas chromatograph equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The carbon balances agreed within ± 5 mol.%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) imaging was performed using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20. The crystal structures were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a PANalytical X’pert diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation source. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area was measured at 77 K using a Micrometrics TriStar porosimeter. The inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was employed to analyze the metal composition of the catalysts using an Agilent 7700 ICP-MS system. The Raman spectra of dry powdered catalyst samples in ambient air were collected using a Horiba T64000 Raman spectrometer (488 nm excitation from a coherent FreD 90C Ar+ laser with a spot size of ∼ 2 μm). The hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) studies were performed using a Stanford Research Systems QMS 200 gas analyzer. The catalyst sample was heated at 5 °C/min from room temperature to 580 °C in 20 vol. % H2 balanced with argon flowing at 10 mL/min (STP). The XPS spectra of the catalysts were collected using a Kratos AXIS Ultra X-ray photoelectron spectrometer for the specific C 1s, O 1s, Co 2p, Mo 3d, Zr 3d, and S 2p regions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of n ML CoMo/ZrO2 catalysts Fig. 1 shows the TEM images of n ML CoMo-S catalysts. The inset of Fig. 1a illustrates the presence of 2.8 Å and 3.7 Å lattice fringes in the 0.5 ML catalyst, which correspond to the (-111) and (110) planes of ZrO2. The small dark dots (white arrow) suggested the presence of CoMo-S, indicating that CoMo-S species partially covered the ZrO2 support since the Co and Mo content in the 0.5 ML catalyst was insufficient to coat entire ZrO2 surface. The inset of Fig. 1b demonstrates less distinct lattice fringes of ZrO2 and a limited number of dark dots (white arrow) than those in the 0.5 ML catalyst, while the blurry edge layers (white circles) appeared on the surface of ZrO2 support. This suggested that the CoMo-S species in the 1 ML catalysts covered the ZrO2 support and formed CoMo-S layer on the ZrO2 support at the monolayer coverage. The 6.2 ∼ 6.8 Å interlayer spacings observed in the surface layers (black circles) in the TEM image of 2 ML catalyst (Fig. 1c) corresponded to those of the MoS2(002) planes [42,43] indicating the formation of CoMo-S layers above the theoretical monolayer coverage. Much thicker CoMo-S multilayers were evident in Fig. 1d, indicating the increased ordering of a conformally layered CoMo-S phases in the 4 ML catalyst. The presence of CoMo-S multilayers in the TEM image of the 4 ML catalyst (Fig. 1d) was in good agreement with the presence of CoMo2S4 in the XRD pattern the 4 ML catalyst (Fig. 2 ). Table 1 summarizes the Co and Mo content (wt.%), BET surface areas, atomic S/Mo ratios, and H2 consumption during H2-TPR analysis of n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts and ZrO2 support. The peaks visible at 2θ = 28.1°, 31.5°, and 34.2° (PDF 00-036-0420) corresponding to the (-111), (111), and (002) reflections of ZrO2 were observed for all ZrO2-supported catalysts. A distinct (200) peak of CoMo2S4 at 2θ = 30.3° (PDF 00-023-0192) was observed in the XRD pattern of the 4 ML catalyst, indicating the formation of highly ordered CoMo-S multilayers. The weak peaks of MoO3 at 2θ = 27.3° (021) (PDF 00-005-0508) and CoMoO4 at 2θ = 32.3° (-222) (PDF 00-025-1434) were observed in the XRD pattern of the 4 ML catalyst, but these peaks were absent in the XRD patterns of other n ML CoMo-S catalysts. 3.2 Characterization of Co/Mo = n catalysts Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of Co/Mo = n catalysts at theoretical monolayer coverage. The inset of Fig. 3a (Co/Mo = 0, Mo-S catalyst) demonstrates the presence of dark spots (black circles) indicating Mo-S species and blurry edge layers (black arrows) corresponding to Mo-S layer on the ZrO2 support. Small dark spots (white arrows) corresponding to CoMo-S species and blurry edge layers (white circles) corresponding to the CoMo-S layers on the ZrO2 support were observed in TEM images of all CoMo-S catalysts (Co/Mo = 0.1, 0.3, and 1.5). The dark spots visible in the TEM images of the CoMo-S catalysts (Fig. 3b, c, d) were smaller than the dark spots in Mo-S catalyst (Fig. 3a), suggesting the formation of smaller sized CoMo-S particles in the CoMo-S catalysts as compared to the Mo-S species in the Mo-S catalyst. These observations suggested that the Co promoter enhanced the dispersion of Mo-S species [44]. In addition, the lattice fringes of CoMo-S multilayers were not observed in the TEM images of CoMo = n catalysts, suggesting that CoMo-S species partially covered ZrO2 surface at theoretical monolayer coverage. No XRD reflections of Co and Mo phases were observed in the XRD patterns of the Co/Mo = n catalysts at theoretical monolayer coverage, whereas all Co/Mo = n catalysts showed the presence of only monoclinic ZrO2 (Fig. S1). Table 1 summarizes the Co and Mo content (wt.%), BET surface areas, atomic S/Mo ratios, activation energies, and TOFs for the WGS reaction, and H2 consumption during H2-TPR analysis of Co/Mo = n catalysts. 3.3 WGS activity of n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts Fig. 4 shows the CO conversion over n ML CoMo-S catalysts at 150 ∼ 450 °C and GHSV = 35,000 h−1 in 7000 ppm H2S-containing feed of 10 vol. % CO and 20 vol. % H2O in helium. The 1 ML, 2 ML, and 4 ML CoMo-S catalysts showed similar CO conversion below 200 °C. Most catalysts showed similar WGS activity at 450 °C, except for the 4 ML catalyst. The lowest CO conversion at 450 °C for the 4 ML catalyst could be explained by the lowest BET surface area of this catalyst among all n ML catalysts. The CO conversion over the 1 ML catalyst was higher than that of other catalysts at 225∼400 °C. This suggests that the CO conversion of n ML CoMo catalysts increased with the surface coverage up to monolayer coverage. Fig. 5 a shows the Raman spectra of the n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts. The peaks at 378 and 402 cm−1 corresponding to the Mo = S stretch were present in the spectra of all catalysts [45]. The intensity of the Mo = S stretch for the n ML CoMo-S catalysts was proportional to the number of CoMo-S layers. On the other hand, the lower intensity of Mo = S stretch in 0.5 ML and 1 ML catalysts indicates the poor crystallinity of the CoMo-S species and the formation of highly dispersed CoMo-S species in the catalysts at (sub)monolayer coverage as compared to that in the multilayer CoMo-S catalysts. The broad peak at 750 cm−1 and strong peak at 996 cm−1 present in the spectra of the 2 ML and 4 ML catalysts corresponded to Zr-O-Mo and Mo = O species, respectively [30], which were absent in other CoMo catalysts at (sub)monolayer coverage. The strong peaks at 816, 872, and 930 cm−1 corresponding to CoMoO4 were observed for the 4 ML CoMo-S catalyst [46,47], while only a broad CoMo oxide peak was observed for other CoMo-S catalysts. The intensity of the ZrO2 peaks decreased with the increasing number of CoMo-S layers, while the intensity of the peaks corresponding to CoMo-S and CoMo-O species increased, suggesting that the CoMo-S species in n ML CoMo-S catalysts covered the ZrO2 support. The Raman spectra further suggested that the subsurface CoMo-O component was present as the MoO3, Zr-O-Mo species, or CoMoO4 in multilayer CoMo-S catalysts, which are not expected to be active for the WGS reaction [11]. Fig. 5b shows the Raman spectra of n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts collected for a step size of 0.2 cm−1 in order to study in-plane (E2g) and out-of-plane vibrations (A1g) of the CoMo-S layer. The van der Waals forces between the neighboring CoMo-S layers could influence the strain of the out-of-plane vibration mode (A1g) [45], while the E2g mode corresponds to the in-plane vibration, that could be influenced by the incorporation of the promoters [45]. Stacked Mo-S layers were reported to show the blue shift of A1g with increasing thickness of Mo-S layers [48–50]. Fig. 5b shows that the position of the A1g mode shifted toward higher wavenumber with increasing number of CoMo-S layers, indicating that the Mo = S stretch in the thicker CoMo-S layers was subject to greater van der Waals forces than those for the (sub)monolayer CoMo-S coverage. The E2g mode of n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts was largely unchanged (379.0∼379.8 cm−1), suggesting similar in-plane strain due to the similar Co/Mo composition in the CoMo-S layers. Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR profiles of n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts after pre-sulfidation. The low-temperature region (160∼195 °C) corresponds to the reduction of weakly bonded surface sulfur atoms in CoMo-S species, the intermediate-temperature region (217∼232 °C) corresponds to the reduction of weakly bonded surface sulfur atoms in Mo-S species [51–53], and the high-temperature region (275∼293 °C) corresponds to the reduction of the residual MoO3 to MoO2 [54]. The trend of Mo-S reduction temperature in supported CoMo catalysts followed the order: 4 ML (218 °C) ≤ 2 ML (217 °C) < 1 ML (227 °C) < 0.5 ML (232 °C), indicating that the reducibility of weakly bonded sulfur in Mo-S was enhanced by increasing the number of CoMo-S layers. This result agreed with the trend of the reduction temperature of CoMo-S species (4 ML: 160 °C < 2 ML: 172 °C < 1 ML: 184 °C < 0.5 ML: 195 °C) and correlated with the extent of sulfidation (S/Mo ratio, 4 ML: 1.8 > 2 ML: 1.7 ≥ 1 ML: 1.7 > 0.5 ML: 1.1) from the XPS analysis (Table 1). The amount of weakly bonded sulfur in Mo-S and CoMo-S species was estimated by the H2 consumption for the corresponding reduction peaks and summarized in Table 1. The largest H2 consumption corresponding to the reduction of surface sulfur in Mo-S and CoMo-S species was observed for the 1 ML CoMo-S catalyst, which corresponded with the highest WGS activity of 1 ML CoMo-S catalyst among all n ML CoMo-S catalysts. The amount of weakly bonded sulfur in 4 ML catalyst decreased by 25% as compared to that for the 1 ML catalyst, which could be attributed to 20 % lower BET surface area of the 4 ML catalyst as compared to that for the 1 ML catalyst, while their extent of sulfidation (atomic S/Mo ratio) estimated by XPS were similar. 3.4 WGS activity of Co/Mo = n catalysts Fig. 7 shows the CO conversion over the Co/Mo = n catalysts and commercial CoMo catalyst at 150 ∼ 450 °C and GHSV = 35,000 h−1 in 7000 ppm H2S-containing feed of 10 vol.% CO and 20 vol.% H2O in helium. The Co/Mo = 1.5 and 0.3 catalysts showed higher CO conversion at 350 ∼ 450 °C than other catalysts that was close to the equilibrium conversion. The Co/Mo = 0.1, 0.3, and 1.5 catalysts showed higher CO conversion below 350 °C than the unpromoted Mo-S catalyst. This indicated that Co addition enhanced the WGS activity of Mo-S catalysts, while the enhancement of CO conversion was manifested in the low-temperature range (250–350 °C). The CO conversion over the Co/Mo = n catalysts at 350 °C increased with Co content up to Co/Mo = 0.3 and then plateaued. It should be noted that cobalt-rich CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalyst (Co/Mo = 1.5) was investigated with respect to the H2S dependence of the CoMo-S catalytic system since the Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst was already highly active at low-temperature and almost reached equilibrium conversion at 400 °C. Fig. S2 shows the Arrhenius plots of CoMo-S/ZrO2 (Co/Mo = n), which were determined at < 13% CO conversion in order to minimize the effects of mass and heat transfer. Our preliminary estimates of the Thiele modulus suggested that all CoMo/ZrO2 catalysts tested were not expected to suffer from intraparticle mass-transfer effects. The Arrhenius plots showed good linearity (Fig. S2) and the activation energies determined were in good agreement with previously reported energies for Mo-based WGS catalysts (40–86 kJ/mol) [53,55,56]. The activation energies (Ea) and turnover frequencies (TOF) of Co/Mo = n CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts at 250 °C were summarized in Table S1. The TOFs of CoMo-S catalysts were higher than that for the unpromoted Mo-S catalyst, suggesting that Co addition enhanced the WGS activity of the Mo-S catalyst at 250 °C, in agreement with the reported trend of the enhanced intrinsic activity of the Al2O3-supported CoMo-S catalysts at low temperature [38]. The enhanced WGS activity of the CoMo-S catalysts could be attributed to the lower H2O dissociation energy barrier on S edge sites of CoMo-S species as compared to the unpromoted Mo-S species [39,41,57]. This is beneficial for the WGS reaction since the H2O dissociation (H2O → OH + H) is the rate-determining step. Moreover, the COOH-mediated associative mechanism has been proposed for the WGS reaction over the CoMo-S catalysts [39,41], which could be favored for the WGS reaction at low temperatures, such as 250 °C, due to increased lifetimes of the surface intermediates at such temperatures. The overall reaction barrier of the COOH-mediated associative mechanism on the S edge of the CoMo-S species was found to be lower than that for the redox mechanism [39] suggesting that the CoMo-S species may be more active than the Mo-S species at low temperatures. Fig. 8 a shows the Raman spectra of the Co/Mo = n catalysts. The peaks at 378 and 402 cm−1 corresponding to the Mo = S stretch were present in all catalysts [45]. The intensity of the Mo = S stretch of the CoMo-S catalysts was lower than that of the unpromoted Mo-S catalyst, which could be attributed to the poor crystallinity of the CoMo-S component. This suggested that the CoMo-S species is highly dispersed on ZrO2 support in CoMo-S catalysts as compared to the Mo-S species in unpromoted Mo-S catalysts. The presence of highly dispersed CoMo-S species agreed with the presence of small dark spots in the TEM images (Fig. 3b). The less intense peaks corresponding to the monoclinic ZrO2 [30] were observed in the Raman spectra of the Co/Mo = n catalysts suggesting that the CoMo-S species covered the surface of ZrO2 support. The weak peak at 996 cm−1 corresponding to the Mo = O stretch was also observed in the spectra of the CoMo-S catalysts (Co/Mo = 0.1, 0.3, and 1.5). The weak shoulders at 872 and 930 cm−1 corresponding to CoMoO4 were observed at higher Co/Mo ratios (Co/Mo = 0.3 and 1.5) [46,47]. However, the peak intensity of Mo or CoMo oxide was not as strong as that of CoMo-S multilayers in the CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts. These weak Raman features observed in the spectra of Co/Mo = n catalysts suggested that the surface coverage in these catalysts essentially corresponded to that of the CoMo-S monolayer without significant crystallization of a Co/Mo oxide phase. Fig. 8b shows the Raman spectra of the Co/Mo = n catalysts collected at a 0.2 cm−1 step size. All Co/Mo = n catalysts showed the similar position of the A1g mode at 400.6∼401.4 cm−1, corresponding to the reported vibration mode of the MoS2 monolayer [48–50] and suggesting the presence of a Mo-S monolayer in all Co/Mo = n catalysts. The E2g mode of the Mo = S stretch in Co/Mo = n catalysts was shifted from 378.2 cm−1 (Mo-S) to 379.0–379.2 cm−1 (CoMo-S), which could be attributed to the contracted CoMo-S lattice after Co incorporation in the Mo-S lattice [48]. The deconvoluted shoulder peaks at 374.6–375.0 cm−1 were assigned to the vibration mode of the Co-S species [58]. The intensity of the Co-S band in the Co/Mo = 1.5 catalyst was stronger than that of the Co/Mo = 0.1 and 0.3 catalysts, suggesting the formation of Co-S species in the Co-rich CoMo-S catalyst. The weak Raman band at 371.0–371.2 cm−1 could be associated with the Mo-O bending mode of some residual Mo-O phase [59]. Fig. 9 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the Co/Mo = n catalysts. The low-temperature region (172–184 °C) corresponding to the reduction of weakly bonded surface sulfur in the CoMo-S species was observed for the CoMo-S catalysts [51,52], while such low-temperature reduction peak was not observed for the Mo-S catalyst. All Co/Mo = n catalysts showed reduction peaks in the intermediate temperature region (206–227 °C) corresponding to the reduction of weakly bonded surface sulfur in the unpromoted Mo-S species [51–53]. The lower reduction temperature of CoMo-S species than that of Mo-S species indicated that the surface sulfur is more weakly bonded to the CoMo component than pure Mo species [60]. This result agreed with the lower sulfur bonding energy in CoMo-S species than in Mo-S species [61]. The H2 consumption during the CoMo-S species reduction increased upon Co addition, reaching a plateau at Co/Mo = 0.3 (Table 1). The H2 consumption during the reduction of Mo-S species in the Co/Mo = 1.5 catalyst was greater than for other catalysts, which could be attributed to the sulfur reduction in the Co-S species, which was not observed for the Co/Mo = 0.1 and 0.3 catalysts. The XPS analysis was performed to investigate the Co-promoter effect on the WGS reaction over Co/Mo = n catalysts (Fig. 10 ). The binding energy (BE) and the relative areas of corresponding XPS peaks are summarized in Table S2. The Mo 3d doublet at 232.2 ± 0.3 eV and 235.4 ± 0.3 eV was observed for the CoMo-S catalysts (Co/Mo = 0.1, 0.3, and 0.5), which was not observed for the Mo-S catalyst (Co/Mo = 0). This suggested that the Mo doublet was associated with the CoMo-S species. The relative area of the Mo doublet corresponding to CoMo-S species increased with Co content up to Co/Mo = 0.3 and plateaued at Co/Mo = 1.5 (Table S2), suggesting that the formation of CoMo-S species was saturated at Co/Mo = 0.3 and excess Co could be present as Co-S species or CoSO4. The characteristic BEs of 228.6 ± 0.2 eV and 231.8 ± 0.2 eV corresponding to Mo4+ (sulfide) in the Co/Mo = n catalysts were observed for all Co/Mo = n catalysts. The BE of Mo4+ (MoS2) was almost unchanged regardless of Co content, suggesting that Co was not incorporated into MoS2. The doublets at 230.0 ± 0.5 eV and 233.3 ± 0.4 eV corresponding to the Mo5+ (oxysulfide) are shown in Fig. 10a and Table S2. The atomic Mo5+/Mo4+ ratios of CoMo-S catalysts (Co/Mo = 1 : 0.51, Co/Mo = 0.0: 0.43, and Co/Mo = 1.5: 0.40) were higher than that of the Mo-S catalyst (0.27), suggesting that Co addition facilitated the formation of oxysulfide species, which were widely proposed as the active sites of Mo-based WGS catalysts [11,32]. A separate peak at 226.1 ± 0.2 eV was observed for all Co/Mo = n catalysts, which is the characteristic BE of S 2 s. The S 2p XPS spectra of the Co/Mo = n catalysts are shown in Fig. 10b. The doublet at 161.5 ± 0.2 eV and 162.7 ± 0.2 eV was associated with S2− (sulfide) [62]. The BE of S2− in the Co/Mo = n catalysts was almost unchanged (161.3 ∼ 161.7 eV) regardless of Co content, suggesting that the Co addition did not influence the S2- (sulfide). The doublets at 163.1 ± 0.7 eV and 164.3 ± 0.7 eV were observed in all Co/Mo = n catalysts [63], which may be attributed to the S2 2− in the oxysulfide and CoMo-S species. The BE of S2 2- in the CoMo-S catalysts experienced a considerable shift (0.9 ∼ 1.3 eV) as compared to that of the Mo-S catalyst (162.4 eV) suggesting that the Co addition mostly influenced the oxysulfide and CoMo-S species. The BE of sulfate (SO4 2−) is identified at 168.0 eV ∼ 168.5 eV in the CoMo-S catalysts, which agreed with the characteristic BE of sulfate in previous reports [62,64,65]. The sulfate (SO4 2−) species may originate from CoSO4 which increased in content with Co addition. The relative area ratio of sulfate (SO4 2−) to the total sulfur species in the CoMo-S catalysts increased with Co content (Table S2), whereas no sulfate was observed by XPS in the Mo-S catalyst. The formation of sulfate could be attributed to the presence of a separate Co component which was not incorporated in the MoS2 lattice. Moreover, water produced during MoO3 sulfidation may react with H2S and Co species to form CoSO4 [66]. As reported previously [34,67], CoS2, Co9S8, CoSO4, and Mo(SO4)2 were detected by the XRD, XPS, and Raman spectroscopy in CoMo-S/Al2O3 catalysts above Co/Mo > 0.5. Therefore, when the Co content in CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts exceeded Co/Mo > 0.3, the excess cobalt may form Co9S8 or CoS2 instead of forming the mixed metal sulfide (CoMo-S) species in the CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts. However, the Co-S species are not responsible for WGS activity [11,68], accounting for the plateaued WGS activity above Co/Mo > 0.3 at low temperatures. 3.5 Long-term stability and H2S-dependence of CoMo-S/ZrO2 WGS catalysts Long-term WGS activity test of the CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts was performed employing H2S-containing feed (Fig. 11 ). The Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst showed stable activity during four weeks of WGS reaction in 7000 ppm H2S-containing feed stream. The CO conversion over the Co/Mo = 1.5 catalyst was stable for first 12 days of WGS reaction, and then declined gradually. The commercial CoMo catalyst showed stable CO conversion during 12 days of WGS reaction, which decreased only by 3%, while the Co/Mo = 0 (Mo-S) catalyst gradually lost its WGS activity. These WGS activity results suggest that the Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst corresponding to theoretical monolayer coverage was the most active among the catalysts investigated in this study that maintained their activity at 350 °C in H2S-containing feed. Fig. 12 shows the CO conversion over (a) n ML and (b) Co/Mo = n catalysts in both H2S-containing and H2S-free feed. These tests were conducted after the temperature-profile tests of these catalysts shown in Figs. 4 and 7. The CO conversion over the 1 ML CoMo-S catalyst decreased by 40% in the absence of H2S in the feed (7–28 h of testing), while the CO conversion of the 0.5 ML, 2 ML, and 4 ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts decreased by 25%, 8%, and 18%, respectively. The WGS activity of 2 ML and 4 ML CoMo-S catalysts decreased slowly as compared to that of 0.5 ML and 1 ML CoMo-S catalysts in the H2S-free feed. This could be attributed to the sulfur diffusion from the sub-surface to the surface layer during the WGS reaction in the H2S-free feed since the S atoms are reported to exhibit significant mobility in multilayer catalysts as compared to monolayer catalysts [69]. The Co/Mo = 0.3 and 1.5 catalysts showed 8–26 % higher CO conversion than the Co/Mo = 0, Co/Mo = 0.1, and commercial sour gas shift catalysts in 7000 ppm H2S-containing feed. The decrease of CO conversion over the CoMo-S catalysts during 7∼ 28 h of WGS reaction in the H2S-free feed stream followed the order: Co/Mo = 1.5 (40% decrease) > Co/Mo = 0.3 (14%) ≥ Co/Mo = 0.1 (10%) > Co/Mo = 0 (6%). This indicated that the H2S dependence of the catalysts increased with Co content in the WGS reaction at 350 °C. The increased H2S dependence of CoMo-S catalyst can be explained by the weakened sulfur bond in CoMo-S species after Co addition. Fig. 13 shows the CO conversion over the Co/Mo = 0.3 and Co/Mo = 1.5 catalysts during 75 h of two cycles of WGS reaction in 7000 ppm H2S-containing or H2S-free feed. Although the CO conversion over the Co/Mo = 1.5 catalyst in the H2S-free feed decreased more significantly as compared to the Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst, both catalysts recovered most of their WGS activity within two hours of WGS reaction in 7000 ppm H2S-containing feed. Table S3 summarizes the atomic S/Mo ratios from the XPS analysis of fresh and used catalysts, the latter having been collected after the WGS reaction in the H2S-free feed. The atomic S/Mo ratio of Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst decreased by 28 % during the WGS reaction in the H2S-free feed, whereas that of the Co/Mo = 1.5 catalyst decreased by 48 %, suggesting that the decrease of CO conversion in the H2S-free feed resulted mostly from the loss of sulfur from the CoMo-S component. The lost sulfur was mainly associated with the weakened sulfur bond in CoMo-S species since the decrease of CO conversion over the unpromoted Mo-S catalyst was minor as compared to the CoMo-S catalysts. As discussed above in relation to H2 TPR and sulfur dependence tests, the sulfur bond of CoMo-S species is weakened upon Co addition. The CO conversion of Co/Mo = 1.5 catalysts decreased by 7 % after two cycles of WGS reaction in H2S-containing and H2S-free feed, while the CO conversion of the Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst was completely recovered. In addition to H2S dependence of the CoMo-S species, this further suggested that the CoMo-S species above Co/Mo>0.3 easily lost sulfur, which could not be fully recovered in the H2S containing feed. This could explain a 10% decrease of CO conversion over the Co/Mo = 1.5 catalyst during 12 days of reaction in 7000 ppm H2S-containing feed. However, the sulfur bond of CoMo-S species in the Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst was stable, as suggested by stable WGS activity during 4 weeks of reaction. These findings indicated that the Co/Mo = 0.3 is the optimal atomic Co/Mo ratio for the CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts. The Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst at monolayer coverage was not only the most active among the CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts investigated in this study but also most stable for WGS reaction in H2S-containing feed at 350 °C. 4 Conclusions A series of CoMo catalysts supported on ZrO2 were synthesized at different CoMo-O surface coverage ranging from 0.5 to 4 ML. Highly dispersed CoMo-S species at monolayer coverage and increased ordering of CoMo-S layers at multilayer coverage were observed by TEM, XRD, and Raman spectroscopy in sulfided n ML CoMo-S catalysts. The WGS activity of these n ML catalysts increased with the surface coverage up to theoretical monolayer and then decreased for the 4 ML catalyst. The atomic S/Mo ratios and H2 reduction of the fresh n ML catalysts were investigated by XPS and H2-TPR, respectively, in order to examine the extent of sulfidation and the amount of weakly bonded surface sulfur, which correlated with the WGS activity of these catalysts. As a result, the WGS activity was optimized for n ML CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalyst and the CO conversion of the CoMo-S catalyst at monolayer coverage was found to reach almost the equilibrium conversion at 400 °C and 35,000 h−1 GHSV. Another series of CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts was prepared by tuning atomic Co/Mo ratio, while their surface coverage was maintained at a theoretical monolayer. Highly dispersed Mo-S and CoMo-S species were observed for the Co/Mo = n catalysts, confirming the formation of a CoMo-S monolayer. The Co addition facilitated the formation of CoMo-S species on ZrO2 support, which increased with Co addition up to Co/Mo = 0.3. The excess Co above Co/Mo = 0.3 in the CoMo-S catalysts was present as Co-S species and CoSO4. The CO conversion over Co/Mo = n catalysts at 350 °C and 35,000 h−1 GHSV also increased with Co content up to Co/Mo = 0.3 and then plateaued at Co/Mo = 1.5, suggesting the improvement of WGS activity was mostly attributed to the increased formation of CoMo-S species. However, the CO conversion over the CoMo-S catalysts at Co/Mo > 0.3 was highly dependent on H2S presence in the feed, which may be explained by the weak sulfur bonding in the CoMo-S species. Therefore, the CoMo-S catalyst at the optimal Co/Mo = 0.3 and containing a CoMo-S monolayer was the most active (>85% CO conversion) and stable (at least 4 weeks) WGS catalyst at 350 °C and 35,000 h−1 GHSV in 7000 ppm H2S-containing feed. coredata.dc:description: A series of CoMo-S/ZrO2 catalysts were prepared by modifying Co and Mo content using incipient wetness impregnation method, investigated in the water gas shift (WGS) reaction in the presence of H2S and characterized by TEM, XRD, Raman, TPR, and XPS. The supported CoMo-S catalyst corresponding to the CoMo-O monolayer coverage displayed the presence of highly dispersed CoMo-S species that were characterized by the highest extent of sulfidation. The presence of cobalt facilitated the formation of active CoMo-S species that were more H2S-dependent as compared to Mo-S entities. The Co/Mo = 0.3 catalyst at monolayer CoMo-O coverage was the most active and thermally stable, as well as the least H2S-dependent during 4 weeks of WGS reaction among all catalysts investigated.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogen production over Co-promoted Mo-S water gas shift catalysts supported on ZrO2
